The Long And Short Of It
Ask any•freshman or upperclassman what he thinks
of Orientation Week. If he has thought about the question,
and most Hopkins men have, he will either want to lengthen
the week or shorten it.
He who wants to lengthen the program will usually
say he feels rushed, doesn't have enough time to digest
what he learns, to assimilate and discuss it, to enjoy the
recreational opportunities offered by The Hopkins, both in
the formal and in the informal sense, and so on. If he is
more honest, and less given to saying little in a great many
words, he will say he wants more time to loaf and more
time to hack.
He who wants to shorten the Orientation Week to
two or three days usually argues like this:
"I came to Hopkins to learn, and I intend to put all
my free time on my studies. This 'Activities Optional',
and the Intramural Athletics time, to say nothing of the
constantly reiterated Honor Commission talk about the
procedures for dealing with violators, who after all number less than one percent of the University, accomplish
very little toward the ultimate objective." This was the
line we heard from our own cross-section of the freshman
class, a percentage somewhat larger than Dr. Gallup's 15
hundred of 150 million.
The happy medium lies somewhere between the two
schools of thought. We did come here to study, but, they
say, a well-rounded person gets better grades and greater
opportunities than a bookworm. It is to introduce the
Freshman to these other aspects of Hopkins life that
Orientation is spread over a full week. For the "assimilating" and "recreation", the loafing and the hacking, the
Levering Hall people hold the Freshman camp. We like

The Long And Short Of It
Ask any•freshman or upperclassman what he thinks
of Orientation Week. If he has thought about the question,
and most Hopkins men have, he will either want to lengthen
the week or shorten it.
He who wants to lengthen the program will usually
say he feels rushed, doesn't have enough time to digest
what he learns, to assimilate and discuss it, to enjoy the
recreational opportunities offered by The Hopkins, both in
the formal and in the informal sense, and so on. If he is
more honest, and less given to saying little in a great many
words, he will say he wants more time to loaf and more
time to hack.
He who wants to shorten the Orientation Week to
two or three days usually argues like this:
"I came to Hopkins to learn, and I intend to put all
my free time on my studies. This 'Activities Optional',
and the Intramural Athletics time, to say nothing of the
constantly reiterated Honor Commission talk about the
procedures for dealing with violators, who after all number less than one percent of the University, accomplish
very little toward the ultimate objective." This was the
line we heard from our own cross-section of the freshman
class, a percentage somewhat larger than Dr. Gallup's 15
hundred of 150 million.
The happy medium lies somewhere between the two
schools of thought. We did come here to study, but, they
say, a well-rounded person gets better grades and greater
opportunities than a bookworm. It is to introduce the
Freshman to these other aspects of Hopkins life that
Orientation is spread over a full week. For the "assimilating" and "recreation", the loafing and the hacking, the
